content: Most of the guys who post here are veterans or active duty. You'd think they would be a little more willing than the average citizen to think and analyze. Think about this. After we invaded Iraq, it was considered anathema to criticize the president in time of war! People that did that were unpatriotic! But it was -okay- in 1944 for the Republicans to charge that FDR had a destroyer sent just to get his little dog, Fala. See how it works? As citizens of this country, you have to do the work. You have to know the history and be smart enough to place it into its proper context. When FOX and other Republican propaganda organs were saying we shouldn't criticize President Bush, they were playing people for fools. And now - of course it is OKAY - it is REQUIRED to go WAY beyond the bounds of acceptable discourse -- in a time of war. Another thing about the Republicans. Once Clinton was fairly elected, they did everything they could to keep him from governing. They were not exactly the loyal opposition. They did not leave politics at the water's edge. And boys and girls, we were just as much at war with AQ then as we are now. Granted, Clinton was a scurvy knave who made a lot of his own problems. But the Republicans failed this country disastrously by the smear campaigns that they ran, and still run. Geez, now it all they have, and all they know. Next thing they will probably do is pass a story that the Obamas sent their dog to England for a shampoo in a C-17. Walt

content: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: quote: Originally posted by WhiskeyPapa: Let me ask you this, yes or no. Do you recall anyone saying that the president (it being Bush at the time) should not be criticized in time of war? Walt I don't recall anyone saying that. I found a good example. "During last night's (4/2/09) “Great American Panel” segment on Hannity, panelist Layla Kayleigh confronted Sean Hannity on his divisive tactics against President Barack Obama. When he insisted he was only being “critical,” she noted that when Democrats criticized President Bush, they were called unpatriotic. “No, they weren't,” Hannity disingenuously said (or else he suffers from amnesia). OK, so maybe they weren't called “unpatriotic.” They were “only” accused of being sick, hating America, undermining the troops and more. With video. The discussion began with Hannity teasingly calling Kayleigh “the only socialist on the panel,” based on her Obama-supporting comments in the previous segment. Kayleigh objected to the characterization and said, “(Obama) can be wrong. But this atttitude that you have is only going to divide us. We have to come together and find solutions.” “Patriotic” Hannity immediately started whining accusatorily, “I can't be critical or else I will divide the country.” “Of course you can be critical,” Kayleigh began. But Hannity had already directed the panel over to Jesse Lee Peterson, Hannity's favorite bigot. Instead of listening to Kayleigh's concerns, Peterson (supposedly an advocate for personal responsibility) pointed the “liberals did it first with President Bush” finger. “When people attacked Bush, they were called unpatriotic,” Kayleigh said. Hannity said resentfully, “Not true. That's not true.” Then he began counting off on his fingers about Democrats, saying, “They said the surge lost, the war was lost.” You could almost hear him longing to attack Democrats further but couldn't when he had just denied being intolerant. So he moved on, pointing to his pal Peterson. So just to correct the record, here are just a few of the things that have been said about Bush critics on Hannity's show, either by him or by a guest he never rebutted: "Why don’t you liberals just admit it? You don’t like the military. It’s all phony when you say you support the troops," Mark Levin (Hannity calls him "The Great One"), 11/2/06 “The left has a disdain for the military... They’re dangerous... trying to undermine the will of the American people." Tom DeLay, 10/31/06 "It’s clear that the Howard Dean, Nancy Pelosi, John Kerry wing of the Democratic Party has a visceral loathing for the American military and for, frankly, America as a country in the world. Their whole approach is to blame us for what, in fact, our enemies do... I think it tells you how deep the sickness is in the left wing of the Democratic Party.” Newt Gingrich, 11/1/06 "That’s your Party that undermines our troop morale and emboldens our enemies," Sean Hannity, 2/1/08. "When you have Democrats saying it's time to get out, artificial timetables and saying that the Commander-in-Chief lied, distorted, hyped and misled the troops. Is that the thing to do during a time of war?" Sean Hannity, 12/2/05 By the way, last I checked, this is still a time of war. Or is calling our president a radical socialist better than calling him a liar?" ------------- These personal attacks are outside what we need to have in order to have a good democractic (small D) discourse in this country. Republicans didn't want Bush criticized in time of war, but they feel it is perfectly okay to attack President Obama is the harshest, most ridiculous terms -- in a time of war. And President Clinton -- What became of the Whitewater investigation? How did proving that Vince Foster was murdered in Hillary's office, or apartment -- how did that ever turn out? These attacks -- the Republican Party stock in trade -- in a time of war, ought to repel good citizens. Good citizens who are engaged and knowledgeable should reject the Republican Party. Is it actually -treason- to call the president a radical socialist? Maybe. It can only give aid and comfort to our enemies. Active Duty and Veterans should have the lead on this. Walt

content: Most of the guys who post here are veterans or active duty. You'd think they would be a little more willing than the average citizen to think and analyze. Think about this. After we invaded Iraq, it was considered anathema to criticize the president in time of war! People that did that were unpatriotic! But it was -okay- in 1944 for the Republicans to charge that FDR had a destroyer sent just to get his little dog, Fala. See how it works? As citizens of this country, you have to do the work. You have to know the history and be smart enough to place it into its proper context. When FOX and other Republican propaganda organs were saying we shouldn't criticize President Bush, they were playing people for fools. And now - of course it is OKAY - it is REQUIRED to go WAY beyond the bounds of acceptable discourse -- in a time of war. Another thing about the Republicans. Once Clinton was fairly elected, they did everything they could to keep him from governing. They were not exactly the loyal opposition. They did not leave politics at the water's edge. And boys and girls, we were just as much at war with AQ then as we are now. Granted, Clinton was a scurvy knave who made a lot of his own problems. But the Republicans failed this country disastrously by the smear campaigns that they ran, and still run. Geez, now it all they have, and all they know. Next thing they will probably do is pass a story that the Obamas sent their dog to England for a shampoo in a C-17. Walt

content: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: quote: Originally posted by WhiskeyPapa: Let me ask you this, yes or no. Do you recall anyone saying that the president (it being Bush at the time) should not be criticized in time of war? Walt I don't recall anyone saying that. I found a good example. "During last night's (4/2/09) “Great American Panel” segment on Hannity, panelist Layla Kayleigh confronted Sean Hannity on his divisive tactics against President Barack Obama. When he insisted he was only being “critical,” she noted that when Democrats criticized President Bush, they were called unpatriotic. “No, they weren't,” Hannity disingenuously said (or else he suffers from amnesia). OK, so maybe they weren't called “unpatriotic.” They were “only” accused of being sick, hating America, undermining the troops and more. With video. The discussion began with Hannity teasingly calling Kayleigh “the only socialist on the panel,” based on her Obama-supporting comments in the previous segment. Kayleigh objected to the characterization and said, “(Obama) can be wrong. But this atttitude that you have is only going to divide us. We have to come together and find solutions.” “Patriotic” Hannity immediately started whining accusatorily, “I can't be critical or else I will divide the country.” “Of course you can be critical,” Kayleigh began. But Hannity had already directed the panel over to Jesse Lee Peterson, Hannity's favorite bigot. Instead of listening to Kayleigh's concerns, Peterson (supposedly an advocate for personal responsibility) pointed the “liberals did it first with President Bush” finger. “When people attacked Bush, they were called unpatriotic,” Kayleigh said. Hannity said resentfully, “Not true. That's not true.” Then he began counting off on his fingers about Democrats, saying, “They said the surge lost, the war was lost.” You could almost hear him longing to attack Democrats further but couldn't when he had just denied being intolerant. So he moved on, pointing to his pal Peterson. So just to correct the record, here are just a few of the things that have been said about Bush critics on Hannity's show, either by him or by a guest he never rebutted: "Why don’t you liberals just admit it? You don’t like the military. It’s all phony when you say you support the troops," Mark Levin (Hannity calls him "The Great One"), 11/2/06 “The left has a disdain for the military... They’re dangerous... trying to undermine the will of the American people." Tom DeLay, 10/31/06 "It’s clear that the Howard Dean, Nancy Pelosi, John Kerry wing of the Democratic Party has a visceral loathing for the American military and for, frankly, America as a country in the world. Their whole approach is to blame us for what, in fact, our enemies do... I think it tells you how deep the sickness is in the left wing of the Democratic Party.” Newt Gingrich, 11/1/06 "That’s your Party that undermines our troop morale and emboldens our enemies," Sean Hannity, 2/1/08. "When you have Democrats saying it's time to get out, artificial timetables and saying that the Commander-in-Chief lied, distorted, hyped and misled the troops. Is that the thing to do during a time of war?" Sean Hannity, 12/2/05 By the way, last I checked, this is still a time of war. Or is calling our president a radical socialist better than calling him a liar?" ------------- These personal attacks are outside what we need to have in order to have a good democractic (small D) discourse in this country. Republicans didn't want Bush criticized in time of war, but they feel it is perfectly okay to attack President Obama is the harshest, most ridiculous terms -- in a time of war. And President Clinton -- What became of the Whitewater investigation? How did proving that Vince Foster was murdered in Hillary's office, or apartment -- how did that ever turn out? These attacks -- the Republican Party stock in trade -- in a time of war, ought to repel good citizens. Good citizens who are engaged and knowledgeable should reject the Republican Party. Is it actually -treason- to call the president a radical socialist? Maybe. It can only give aid and comfort to our enemies. Active Duty and Veterans should have the lead on this. Walt
quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: quote: Originally posted by WhiskeyPapa: Let me ask you this, yes or no. Do you recall anyone saying that the president (it being Bush at the time) should not be criticized in time of war? Walt I don't recall anyone saying that.

content: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: quote: Originally posted by WhiskeyPapa: Let me ask you this, yes or no. Do you recall anyone saying that the president (it being Bush at the time) should not be criticized in time of war? Walt I don't recall anyone saying that. I found a good example. "During last night's (4/2/09) “Great American Panel” segment on Hannity, panelist Layla Kayleigh confronted Sean Hannity on his divisive tactics against President Barack Obama. When he insisted he was only being “critical,” she noted that when Democrats criticized President Bush, they were called unpatriotic. “No, they weren't,” Hannity disingenuously said (or else he suffers from amnesia). OK, so maybe they weren't called “unpatriotic.” They were “only” accused of being sick, hating America, undermining the troops and more. With video. The discussion began with Hannity teasingly calling Kayleigh “the only socialist on the panel,” based on her Obama-supporting comments in the previous segment. Kayleigh objected to the characterization and said, “(Obama) can be wrong. But this atttitude that you have is only going to divide us. We have to come together and find solutions.” “Patriotic” Hannity immediately started whining accusatorily, “I can't be critical or else I will divide the country.” “Of course you can be critical,” Kayleigh began. But Hannity had already directed the panel over to Jesse Lee Peterson, Hannity's favorite bigot. Instead of listening to Kayleigh's concerns, Peterson (supposedly an advocate for personal responsibility) pointed the “liberals did it first with President Bush” finger. “When people attacked Bush, they were called unpatriotic,” Kayleigh said. Hannity said resentfully, “Not true. That's not true.” Then he began counting off on his fingers about Democrats, saying, “They said the surge lost, the war was lost.” You could almost hear him longing to attack Democrats further but couldn't when he had just denied being intolerant. So he moved on, pointing to his pal Peterson. So just to correct the record, here are just a few of the things that have been said about Bush critics on Hannity's show, either by him or by a guest he never rebutted: "Why don’t you liberals just admit it? You don’t like the military. It’s all phony when you say you support the troops," Mark Levin (Hannity calls him "The Great One"), 11/2/06 “The left has a disdain for the military... They’re dangerous... trying to undermine the will of the American people." Tom DeLay, 10/31/06 "It’s clear that the Howard Dean, Nancy Pelosi, John Kerry wing of the Democratic Party has a visceral loathing for the American military and for, frankly, America as a country in the world. Their whole approach is to blame us for what, in fact, our enemies do... I think it tells you how deep the sickness is in the left wing of the Democratic Party.” Newt Gingrich, 11/1/06 "That’s your Party that undermines our troop morale and emboldens our enemies," Sean Hannity, 2/1/08. "When you have Democrats saying it's time to get out, artificial timetables and saying that the Commander-in-Chief lied, distorted, hyped and misled the troops. Is that the thing to do during a time of war?" Sean Hannity, 12/2/05 By the way, last I checked, this is still a time of war. Or is calling our president a radical socialist better than calling him a liar?" ------------- These personal attacks are outside what we need to have in order to have a good democractic (small D) discourse in this country. Republicans didn't want Bush criticized in time of war, but they feel it is perfectly okay to attack President Obama is the harshest, most ridiculous terms -- in a time of war. And President Clinton -- What became of the Whitewater investigation? How did proving that Vince Foster was murdered in Hillary's office, or apartment -- how did that ever turn out? These attacks -- the Republican Party stock in trade -- in a time of war, ought to repel good citizens. Good citizens who are engaged and knowledgeable should reject the Republican Party. Is it actually -treason- to call the president a radical socialist? Maybe. It can only give aid and comfort to our enemies. Active Duty and Veterans should have the lead on this. Walt

They’re dangerous... trying to undermine the will of the American people." Tom DeLay, 10/31/06 "It’s clear that the Howard Dean, Nancy Pelosi, John Kerry wing of the Democratic Party has a visceral loathing for the American military and for, frankly, America as a country in the world. Their whole approach is to blame us for what, in fact, our enemies do... I think it tells you how deep the sickness is in the left wing of the Democratic Party.” Newt Gingrich, 11/1/06 "That’s your Party that undermines our troop morale and emboldens our enemies," Sean Hannity, 2/1/08. "When you have Democrats saying it's time to get out, artificial timetables and saying that the Commander-in-Chief lied, distorted, hyped and misled the troops. Is that the thing to do during a time of war?" Sean Hannity, 12/2/05 By the way, last I checked, this is still a time of war. Or is calling our president a radical socialist better than calling him a liar?" ------------- These personal attacks are outside what we need to have in order to have a good democractic (small D) discourse in this country. Republicans didn't want Bush criticized in time of war, but they feel it is perfectly okay to attack President Obama is the harshest, most ridiculous terms -- in a time of war. And President Clinton -- What became of the Whitewater investigation? How did proving that Vince Foster was murdered in Hillary's office, or apartment -- how did that ever turn out? These attacks -- the Republican Party stock in trade -- in a time of war, ought to repel good citizens. Good citizens who are engaged and knowledgeable should reject the Republican Party. Is it actually -treason- to call the president a radical socialist? Maybe. It can only give aid and comfort to our enemies. Active Duty and Veterans should have the lead on this. Walt

content: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: quote: Originally posted by WhiskeyPapa: Let me ask you this, yes or no. Do you recall anyone saying that the president (it being Bush at the time) should not be criticized in time of war? Walt I don't recall anyone saying that. I found a good example. "During last night's (4/2/09) “Great American Panel” segment on Hannity, panelist Layla Kayleigh confronted Sean Hannity on his divisive tactics against President Barack Obama. When he insisted he was only being “critical,” she noted that when Democrats criticized President Bush, they were called unpatriotic. “No, they weren't,” Hannity disingenuously said (or else he suffers from amnesia). OK, so maybe they weren't called “unpatriotic.” They were “only” accused of being sick, hating America, undermining the troops and more. With video. The discussion began with Hannity teasingly calling Kayleigh “the only socialist on the panel,” based on her Obama-supporting comments in the previous segment. Kayleigh objected to the characterization and said, “(Obama) can be wrong. But this atttitude that you have is only going to divide us. We have to come together and find solutions.” “Patriotic” Hannity immediately started whining accusatorily, “I can't be critical or else I will divide the country.” “Of course you can be critical,” Kayleigh began. But Hannity had already directed the panel over to Jesse Lee Peterson, Hannity's favorite bigot. Instead of listening to Kayleigh's concerns, Peterson (supposedly an advocate for personal responsibility) pointed the “liberals did it first with President Bush” finger. “When people attacked Bush, they were called unpatriotic,” Kayleigh said. Hannity said resentfully, “Not true. That's not true.” Then he began counting off on his fingers about Democrats, saying, “They said the surge lost, the war was lost.” You could almost hear him longing to attack Democrats further but couldn't when he had just denied being intolerant. So he moved on, pointing to his pal Peterson. So just to correct the record, here are just a few of the things that have been said about Bush critics on Hannity's show, either by him or by a guest he never rebutted: "Why don’t you liberals just admit it? You don’t like the military. It’s all phony when you say you support the troops," Mark Levin (Hannity calls him "The Great One"), 11/2/06 “The left has a disdain for the military... They’re dangerous... trying to undermine the will of the American people." Tom DeLay, 10/31/06 "It’s clear that the Howard Dean, Nancy Pelosi, John Kerry wing of the Democratic Party has a visceral loathing for the American military and for, frankly, America as a country in the world. Their whole approach is to blame us for what, in fact, our enemies do... I think it tells you how deep the sickness is in the left wing of the Democratic Party.” Newt Gingrich, 11/1/06 "That’s your Party that undermines our troop morale and emboldens our enemies," Sean Hannity, 2/1/08. "When you have Democrats saying it's time to get out, artificial timetables and saying that the Commander-in-Chief lied, distorted, hyped and misled the troops. Is that the thing to do during a time of war?" Sean Hannity, 12/2/05 By the way, last I checked, this is still a time of war. Or is calling our president a radical socialist better than calling him a liar?" ------------- These personal attacks are outside what we need to have in order to have a good democractic (small D) discourse in this country. Republicans didn't want Bush criticized in time of war, but they feel it is perfectly okay to attack President Obama is the harshest, most ridiculous terms -- in a time of war. And President Clinton -- What became of the Whitewater investigation? How did proving that Vince Foster was murdered in Hillary's office, or apartment -- how did that ever turn out? These attacks -- the Republican Party stock in trade -- in a time of war, ought to repel good citizens. Good citizens who are engaged and knowledgeable should reject the Republican Party. Is it actually -treason- to call the president a radical socialist? Maybe. It can only give aid and comfort to our enemies. Active Duty and Veterans should have the lead on this. Walt

content: Most of the guys who post here are veterans or active duty. You'd think they would be a little more willing than the average citizen to think and analyze. Think about this. After we invaded Iraq, it was considered anathema to criticize the president in time of war! People that did that were unpatriotic! But it was -okay- in 1944 for the Republicans to charge that FDR had a destroyer sent just to get his little dog, Fala. See how it works? As citizens of this country, you have to do the work. You have to know the history and be smart enough to place it into its proper context. When FOX and other Republican propaganda organs were saying we shouldn't criticize President Bush, they were playing people for fools. And now - of course it is OKAY - it is REQUIRED to go WAY beyond the bounds of acceptable discourse -- in a time of war. Another thing about the Republicans. Once Clinton was fairly elected, they did everything they could to keep him from governing. They were not exactly the loyal opposition. They did not leave politics at the water's edge. And boys and girls, we were just as much at war with AQ then as we are now. Granted, Clinton was a scurvy knave who made a lot of his own problems. But the Republicans failed this country disastrously by the smear campaigns that they ran, and still run. Geez, now it all they have, and all they know. Next thing they will probably do is pass a story that the Obamas sent their dog to England for a shampoo in a C-17. Walt

content: quote: Originally posted by Kegler300: quote: Originally posted by WhiskeyPapa: Let me ask you this, yes or no. Do you recall anyone saying that the president (it being Bush at the time) should not be criticized in time of war? Walt I don't recall anyone saying that. I found a good example. "During last night's (4/2/09) “Great American Panel” segment on Hannity, panelist Layla Kayleigh confronted Sean Hannity on his divisive tactics against President Barack Obama. When he insisted he was only being “critical,” she noted that when Democrats criticized President Bush, they were called unpatriotic. “No, they weren't,” Hannity disingenuously said (or else he suffers from amnesia). OK, so maybe they weren't called “unpatriotic.” They were “only” accused of being sick, hating America, undermining the troops and more. With video. The discussion began with Hannity teasingly calling Kayleigh “the only socialist on the panel,” based on her Obama-supporting comments in the previous segment. Kayleigh objected to the characterization and said, “(Obama) can be wrong. But this atttitude that you have is only going to divide us. We have to come together and find solutions.” “Patriotic” Hannity immediately started whining accusatorily, “I can't be critical or else I will divide the country.” “Of course you can be critical,” Kayleigh began. But Hannity had already directed the panel over to Jesse Lee Peterson, Hannity's favorite bigot. Instead of listening to Kayleigh's concerns, Peterson (supposedly an advocate for personal responsibility) pointed the “liberals did it first with President Bush” finger. “When people attacked Bush, they were called unpatriotic,” Kayleigh said. Hannity said resentfully, “Not true. That's not true.” Then he began counting off on his fingers about Democrats, saying, “They said the surge lost, the war was lost.” You could almost hear him longing to attack Democrats further but couldn't when he had just denied being intolerant. So he moved on, pointing to his pal Peterson. So just to correct the record, here are just a few of the things that have been said about Bush critics on Hannity's show, either by him or by a guest he never rebutted: "Why don’t you liberals just admit it? You don’t like the military. It’s all phony when you say you support the troops," Mark Levin (Hannity calls him "The Great One"), 11/2/06 “The left has a disdain for the military... They’re dangerous... trying to undermine the will of the American people." Tom DeLay, 10/31/06 "It’s clear that the Howard Dean, Nancy Pelosi, John Kerry wing of the Democratic Party has a visceral loathing for the American military and for, frankly, America as a country in the world. Their whole approach is to blame us for what, in fact, our enemies do... I think it tells you how deep the sickness is in the left wing of the Democratic Party.” Newt Gingrich, 11/1/06 "That’s your Party that undermines our troop morale and emboldens our enemies," Sean Hannity, 2/1/08. "When you have Democrats saying it's time to get out, artificial timetables and saying that the Commander-in-Chief lied, distorted, hyped and misled the troops. Is that the thing to do during a time of war?" Sean Hannity, 12/2/05 By the way, last I checked, this is still a time of war. Or is calling our president a radical socialist better than calling him a liar?" ------------- These personal attacks are outside what we need to have in order to have a good democractic (small D) discourse in this country. Republicans didn't want Bush criticized in time of war, but they feel it is perfectly okay to attack President Obama is the harshest, most ridiculous terms -- in a time of war. And President Clinton -- What became of the Whitewater investigation? How did proving that Vince Foster was murdered in Hillary's office, or apartment -- how did that ever turn out? These attacks -- the Republican Party stock in trade -- in a time of war, ought to repel good citizens. Good citizens who are engaged and knowledgeable should reject the Republican Party. Is it actually -treason- to call the president a radical socialist? Maybe. It can only give aid and comfort to our enemies. Active Duty and Veterans should have the lead on this. Walt
